title: The Deployment of End-to-End Audio Language Models Should Take into Account the Principle of Least Privilege
author: Luxi He (Princeton University), Xiangyu Qi (Princeton University), Michel Liao (Princeton University), Inyoung Cheong (Princeton University), Prateek Mittal (Princeton University), Danqi Chen (Princeton University), Peter Henderson (Princeton University), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses the safety and legal implications of end-to-end audio language models, which is directly related to Haohe Liu's research in audio, speech, and AI ethics, particularly in the context of responsible AI deployment.
background: This paper explores the risks of deploying end-to-end audio language models that can infer sensitive information, urging for a principle of least privilege in their use.
contribution: This paper introduces the principle of least privilege to mitigate risks associated with end-to-end audio language models, aiming to reduce potential misuse of sensitive information.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior works typically focused on the performance of audio language models without adequately addressing the security risks posed by end-to-end systems.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes the need for careful evaluation of necessary audio features, advocating for a cautious approach to model deployment that aligns capabilities with actual task requirements.

key_innovation: Advocates for a risk-aware framework that allows only essential audio feature access during model deployment, potentially reducing privacy violations.
real_world_impact: This paper highlights the importance of responsible AI usage in deploying language models, which can influence policies and practices in AI development and deployment in various sectors.
limitations: The authors do not explicitly mention any limitations.

new_terms.principle of least privilege: **Principle of least privilege** is a security concept that states that any user, program, or system should only have access to the information necessary to perform their function, minimizing potential harm from misuse.

open_sourcing: For code and audio samples, please see https://github.com/princeton-polaris-lab/AudioLM-position-paper
